The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. div.head: Die Iovis 2 Junii. 1642.
div.p: WHereas it doth appeare to the Lords and Commons in Parliament, That the King, ≈øeduced by wicked Coun≈øell, doth intend to leavy Warre against his Parliament; and whereas information hath beene given; That the Iewels of the Crowne (which by the law of the land ought not to be alienated) are either pawned or ≈øold in Am≈øterdam, or ≈øome other parts beyond the Seas, and thereby great Sums of money provided to be returned to York, or to ≈øome of his Majesties Servants or Agents for His Maje≈øties u≈øe: And whereas tis more then probable, That this great Provi≈øion of Monyes in ≈øuch an extraordinary way, is to maintaine this intended warre, and thereby to bring the whole Kingdome into utter ruine and combustion. It is therefore declared by the Lords and Commons in Parliament. That who≈øoever hath beene, or ≈øhall be an Actor in the ≈øelling or pawning of any of the Iewels of the Crowne, or hath, or ≈øhall pay, lend, ≈øend, or bring any Money in Specie into this Kingdome, for, or upon any of tho≈øe Iewels; Or who≈øoever hath or ≈øhall accept of any Bill from beyond the Seas, for the payment of any ≈øumme of money for, or upon any of tho≈øe Iewels, and ≈øhall pa≈ø≈øe any ≈øumme according to ≈øuch Bill, after notice of this Order, without acquainting this Hou≈øe with the receipt of ≈øuch Bill before he accept the ≈øame; Or if he have already accepted any ≈øuch Bill, then with the acceptance thereof before the payment of the mony, Every ≈øuch per≈øon ≈øhall be held and accounted a promoter of this intended warre, an enemy to the State, and ought to give ≈øatisfaction for this publick dammage out of His owne E≈øtate.

div.p: ARTICLES OF PEACE and COMMERCE, Between the High and Mighty Kings, CHARLES, by the grace of God, King of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
And JOHN the 4th King of Portugal, Algarres, &c. And their SUBJECTS, Concluded at London the nine and twentieth day of January, in the yeer of our Lord 1642. Stilo novo.

p.hi: Tran≈ølated out of Latin into Engli≈øh.

div.p: LONDON: Printed by ROBERT BARKER, Printer to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie: And by the A≈ø≈øignes of JOHN BILL. 1642.

div.head: ¬∂ By the King.
div.p:
WHereas the High and Mighty Prince, John the fourth, King of Portugall, &c. hath lately ≈øent his Amba≈ø≈øadours to the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie, declaring his de≈øire to renew the ancient Confederation and Amity between their Royall Predece≈ø≈øours, Crowns and Subjects; His Maje≈øtie out of His royall Care of the Peace and Tranquillity of His Kingdoms, and the freedom of Trade and Commerce of His loving Subjects, By the advice of His Privie Councell, hath been plea≈øed to yeeld
thereunto, and doth make known to His loving people, That the ≈øaid Peace and Confederation is concluded and e≈øtabli≈øhed between the ≈øaid Kings, their Crowns, Kingdoms, Territories and Subjects: And the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øtie, for the direction of His Merchants in their Trade and Commerce, hath given Command, That the Articles of this Treatie of Peace ≈øhall be publi≈øhed, ≈øtraitly charging and commanding all His Subjects of what≈øoever degree and e≈øtate to ob≈øerve the ≈øame.

dateline.hi: Given at the Court at York
dateline.date: the two and twentieth day of May, in the eighteenth yeer of His Maje≈øties Reign. 1642.

div.head: I.
div.p:
FIr≈øt, it is concluded and accorded, that there is and ≈øhall be for ever a good, true, and firm Peace and Amitie between the mo≈øt renowned Kings, CHARLES, King of Great Britain, and JOHN the fourth, King of Portugall, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, and their Kingdoms, Countries, Dominions, Lands, Peoples, Liegemen, Va≈ø≈øalls and Subjects whom≈øoever, pre≈øent, and to come, of what≈øoever Condition, Dignity & Degree they maybe, as well by Land
as by Sea, and Fre≈øh-waters, ≈øo as the ≈øaid Va≈ø≈øalls and Subjects are each of them to favour other, and to u≈øe one and other with friendly offices and true affection; And that neither of the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned Kings, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, by him≈øelf or by any other, ≈øhall do or attempt any thing again≈øt each other, or their Kingdoms, by Land or by Sea, nor ≈øhall con≈øent nor adhere unto any War, Coun≈øell, or Treatie in prejudice of the other.

div.head: II.
div.p:
That between the mo≈øt renowned Kings afore≈øaid, and the Va≈ø≈øalls, Inhabitants, and Subjects of each of them, as well by Land, as by Sea and Fre≈øh-waters, in all and ≈øingular their Kingdoms, Dominions, I≈ølands, and other Lands, Cities, Towns, Villages, Havens, and Territories of the ≈øaid Kingdoms and Dominions, there is and ≈øhall be free Commerce (in which there was in the time of the Kings of Ca≈øteele, or hitherto hath been Commerce) ≈øo that without any Safe-Conduct, or other Licence generall or ≈øpeciall, as well by Land, as by Sea and Fre≈øh-waters, the Subjects and Va≈ø≈øalls of each King may and ≈øhall
go, enter, and ≈øail, in and to the Kingdoms and Dominions afore≈øaid, and the Cities, Towns, Havens, Shores, Sea-Rodes, and Territories of the ≈øame, and with Carriages, Hor≈øes, Burdens, Ships loaden or to be loaden, to bring in Merchandizes, to buy or ≈øell, as much as they will, Victuals, and upon ju≈øt Prices to make provi≈øion of things nece≈ø≈øary for their ≈øu≈øtenance and Voyages, and to repair their Shipping and Carriages of their own propertie, or hired, or borrowed by them, and from thence al≈øo with the ≈øame freedom to depart with their Merchandizes, Goods, and things what≈øoever, having paid onely ≈øuch Cu≈øtomes and Tolles, as according to the Ordinances of each place are at that time rated, and may thence go without let or impediment unto their own Countries, or any other places where and how they plea≈øe.

div.head: III.
div.p:
And that the Subjects of each of the mo≈øt renowned Kings before named, in the Dominions and Territories of the other, ≈øhall not be wor≈øe dealt withall then the naturall Subjects in their Sales and Contracts for their Merchandizes,
as well for Price as otherwi≈øe, but that the condition of Forreigners and naturall Subjects ≈øhall be equall and alike as afore≈øaid, according to the practice of ancient Treaties made between the mo≈øt renowned Kings of Great Britain and Ca≈øteele.

div.head: IV.
div.p: That the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain ≈øhall at their own free will and plea≈øure u≈øe and enjoy any kinde of Merchandizes and Trading in Merchandize, in the Kingdoms, Provinces, Territories and I≈ølands of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, in Europe; and that they ≈øhall as freely and in the ≈øame manner exerci≈øe their Trade of Merchandizes in the places afore≈øaid, as is permitted to the Subjects of other Princes and States in League with the King of Portugall; neither ≈øhall they be more burdened with Cu≈øtoms, Impo≈øitions, or other Taxes, then the Inhabitants and Subjects of the ≈øaid Lands, or other Subjects of any Nation what≈øoever in League with the Portugalls, and they ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øame Priviledges which were granted to the Engli≈øh before Portugall was united to Casteele.

div.head: V.
div.p: That when≈øoever the Subjects of the King of Great Britain ≈øhall with their Ships arrive at the Havens of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall in his Kingdoms and Dominions, they ≈øhall not be con≈øtrained by the Mini≈øters, Officers, and Subjects of the King of Portugall, to put or load into their ≈øhips any other kinde or quantities of goods and merchandizes, then it ≈øhall plea≈øe and ≈øeem good unto the ≈øaid Subjects of the King of Great Britain: And that the Subjects of the King of Portugall ≈øhall enjoy the ≈øame freedome in the Havens and Dominions of the King of Great Britain.

div.head: VI.
div.p:
That if it ≈øhall happen that the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, or any other within his Kingdomes and Dominions, or their merchandizes and goods ≈øhall be taken, ≈øea≈øed or arre≈øted by the Office of the Court of Inqui≈øition, or the Judges, or Mini≈øters thereof, which have been or ≈øhall be ingaged or indebted to the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain, the ≈øaid debts ≈øhall be fully paid
out of the ≈øaid goods and merchandizes, within the yeer immediately following the ≈øaid arre≈øt, without any hinderance or trouble of the ≈øaid Court, or the Judges and Mini≈øters of the ≈øame who≈øoever: And if any of the goods and merchandizes of the ≈øaid Subjects of the King of Great Britain, ≈øhall remain in ≈øpecie among the ≈øaid goods and merchandizes ≈øo ≈øeized and arre≈øted, the ≈øame ≈øhall be immediately re≈øtored unto them.

div.head: VII.
div.p: That the Captains, Ma≈øters, Officers, and Mariners of the ≈øhips of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain, or his Subjects, ≈øhall not commence any Actions, nor procure any trouble again≈øt the ≈øaid ≈øhips, or any the Subjects of the ≈øaid King, within the Kingdoms and Dominions of the King of Portugall, for their wages or ≈øalaries, under colour or pretext that they profe≈ø≈øe the Roman Religion, or ≈øhall have put them≈øelves into the ≈øervice of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall.

div.head: VIII.
div.p: That the Con≈øuls named and appointed by the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain, for the aid and protection of his Subjects, remaining within the Kingdoms and Dominions of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, ≈øhall fully and freely exerci≈øe the power and authority of Con≈øuls within the ≈øaid Kingdoms and Dominions, although they ≈øhall not profe≈ø≈øe the Roman Religion.

div.head: IX.
div.p:
That if any Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain ≈øhall depart this life within the Kingdoms and Dominions of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, the books, accounts, merchandizes and goods of them, or of any other Subjects of the ≈øaid King of Great Britain, ≈øhall not from henceforth be taken or ≈øeized by the Judges of Orphans and Ab≈øents, or their Mini≈øters, or Officers, neither ≈øhall they be ≈øubject to their Juri≈ødiction; but the ≈øame goods, merchandizes and accounts, ≈øhall be delivered, by the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øors of them, to Engli≈øh Agents, or Factors
re≈øiding in that City, named and appointed by the ≈øaid Decea≈øed: And if he ≈øhall have named none while he lived, they ≈øhall be delivered to one or two Engli≈øh Merchants, (provided they be Bachelors) by authority of the Con≈øervator of the Engli≈øh, having fir≈øt given Caution with good Sureties to be allowed by the ≈øaid Con≈øervator, to re≈øtore the ≈øaid Goods & Merchandizes to the true Owners thereof, or their lawfull Creditors: And tho≈øe Goods which ≈øhall appear to belong to the Decea≈øed, ≈øhall be delivered to his Heirs, Executors, or Creditors.

div.head: X
div.p:
That the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, or his Mini≈øters within his Kingdoms and Dominions, ≈øhall not arre≈øt, or withhold the Ships of the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain, or his Subjects, without his knowledge and con≈øent, for his ≈øervices of War, or any other ≈øervices what≈øoever; But that the ≈øaid Ships and Subjects may freely, and at their own plea≈øure depart out of the Ports and Dominions of the ≈øaid King, without any hinderance of the ≈øaid King of Portugall, or his Mini≈øters: And that
the Goods and Merchandizes of the Subjects of the King of Great Britain ≈øhall not be taken for the ≈øervice of the King of Portugall, but for the ju≈øt and common-price thereof, to be paid within two Moneths following, unle≈ø≈øe ≈øome other time of paiment ≈øhall be agreed on by both parts.

div.head: XI.
div.p:
That the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain ≈øhall freely carry in their Ships all things, Goods and Merchandizes, of what kinde ≈øoever they be, even Arms, Victuals, or any other of the like kinde out of the Ports and Dominions of the ≈øaid King, or of any Ports and Dominions what≈øoever, (≈øo that they be not immediately carried out of the Ports of Portugall, or the Dominions thereof) to be tran≈øported to any Ports and Territories of the mo≈øt renowned King of Ca≈øteele; And that the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, or his Subjects, ≈øhall not by Seizures, Reprizalls, or any other means hinder the ≈øaid Ships, Goods and Per≈øons of the Subjects of the King of Great Britain, but that they may ≈øafely Sail to the Ports and Territories of the ≈øaid King of Ca≈øteele, and
there exerci≈øe their Merchandize and Trade: And that the Subjects of the Kings of Great Britain and Portugall ≈øhall on both parts have the ≈øame Power, if hereafter it ≈øhall happen that either of the ≈øaid Kings ≈øhall have War with the Friend of the other, and the Subjects of the King of Great Britain ≈øhall carry all kinde of Merchandize, even Arms, Victualls, or any other of the like kinde, with the ≈øame Freedom into the Kingdoms and Dominions of the King of Portugall, and ≈øhall there ≈øell the ≈øame at their own plea≈øure, in publike Market, or privately, without any hinderance of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, or his Mini≈øters.

div.head: XII.
div.p:
Item, That the convention of Truce made between D. Michael de Loronha, Conde de Linhares Vice-Roy of Goa, and William Methwold Pre≈øident of the Engli≈øh in Ea≈øt India, the 20th of January 1635. Stilo novo, ≈øhall be continued and kept between the Subjects of both Kings in East India, and in all the Dominions of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall beyond Cape Bona Speranza; And that the Commi≈ø≈øioners to be
named by the ≈øaid Kings, ≈øhall in East India take Cognizance within three yeers of the Demands which have been or ≈øhall be made by the Subjects and Va≈ø≈øalls of both Kings, for their Commerce in India afore≈øaid, that ≈øo a perpetuall Peace and Confederation may be confirmed and e≈øtabli≈øhed by the ≈øaid Kings, between their Subjects on both parts.

div.head: XIII.
div.p:
And becau≈øe the Commerce and free coming of the Subjects of the King of Great Britain to the Coa≈øts and parts of Africa, the I≈øland of S. Thome, and other I≈ølands comprehended under them, could not yet be agreed on by rea≈øon of the defect of the Powers ≈øent by the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall to his Amba≈ø≈øadors, that by this debate this pre≈øent Treatie of Peace and Amitie between both Kings and their Subjects be not delayed, it is on both parts concluded on, That in the Lands, Places, Ca≈øtles, Ports, and Coa≈øts of Africa, Guyne, Bine, &c. the I≈øland of S. Thome, and other I≈ølands comprehended under them, wherein it ≈øhall appear that the Subjects of Great Britain have dwelt for Trade
of Merchandize, or have had Trade or Commerce there in the time of the Kings of Ca≈øteele, or hitherto, there ≈øhall be no alteration or change, neither ≈øhall they have any trouble or injury done them by the Portugalls for that cau≈øe. And if any Cu≈øtomes be to be demanded from the Subjects of the King of Great Britain, on any cau≈øe, in the Ca≈øtles, I≈ølands, and Places afore≈øaid, they ≈øhall not be greater or more grievous then tho≈øe which ≈øhall be demanded from other Nations in League with the King of Portugall: And the Subjects of the King of Portugall wanting Forreign Ships for their Navigation and Commerce to the Coa≈øts and I≈ølands afore≈øaid, may freely at their own plea≈øure hire the Ships of the Subjects of the King of Great Britain: And that Commi≈ø≈øioners and Amba≈ø≈øadors ≈øhall be named by both Kings, who ≈øhall Treat and Conclude concerning the Commerce and free coming to the Coa≈øts, I≈ølands, and Places afore≈øaid, which hath been demanded by the Commi≈ø≈øioners of the King of Great Britain, for the Subjects of their King, being per≈øwaded out of the confidence of the ancient amity which hath been between the Predece≈ø≈øors of the ≈øame Kings, that
the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall will grant to no Nation more ample Rights, Immunities and Priviledges, then he will grant unto the Subjects of the King of Great Britain.

div.head: XIV.
div.p: And fora≈ømuch as the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall by his Grant, confirmed by his Seal, dated in Lisbone the 21. day of January, in the yeer of the birth of Our Lord, 1641. hath given free power to the Inhabitants of the Lands ≈øubject to the Dominions of the States of Holland, &c. to bring in, and to export all kinde of Merchandizes out of his Kingdoms, Dominions, and Territories, That the Subjects of the King of Great Britain ≈øhall have, and enjoy the ≈øame Power in the Kingdoms and Dominions of the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, according to the Tenour of the ≈øaid Grant.

div.head: XV.
div.p:
And that the Engli≈øh Merchants, and other Subjects of the King of Great Britain, ≈øhall enjoy as great, and the ≈øame Immunitie from being Impri≈øoned, Arre≈øted or any other way troubled
in their Per≈øons, Hou≈øes, Books of Accompts, and Accompts, Merchandizes and Goods within the Dominions of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, as hath been granted, or ≈øhall be hereafter granted to any other Prince, or People in league with the King of Portugall.

div.head: XVI.
div.p: And becau≈øe there is yet no agreement made concerning Fraighting of the Ships of the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain by the Portugalls, for their Commerce and Navigation into Bra≈øill, it hath plea≈øed both Parties, that Commi≈ø≈øioners or Amba≈ø≈øadours ≈øhall be appointed, and ≈øent by the ≈øaid Kings within two yeers, who ≈øhall have power to treat and agree concerning this Article.

div.head: XVII.
div.p:
And becau≈øe the Rights of Commerce and Peace ≈øhall be made unprofitable, if the Subjects of the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain ≈øhall be troubled for their con≈øciences, while they go to and from the Kingdoms and Dominions of the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall, or
re≈øide there for Commerce or Bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; Therefore that their Commerce be ≈øafe and ≈øecure, as well on Land as on Sea, the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall ≈øhall take care, and provide that they ≈øhall not be mole≈øted or di≈øturbed for the ≈øaid Ca≈øe of Con≈øcience, ≈øo as they give not ≈øcandall unto others. And although the mo≈øt renowned King of Portugall do acknowledge that he hath not power to determine and di≈øpo≈øe of Faith and Religion, yet out of his love and great affection to the mo≈øt renowned King of Great Britain, and the Engli≈øh Nation, he ≈øhall take care that the Engli≈øh, and other Subjects of the ≈øaid King, ≈øhall have and enjoy as great Liberty in the practice and exerci≈øe of their Religion within the Kingdoms, Dominions, and Territories of the King of Portugall, as ≈øhall be permitted to the Subjects of any other Prince, or Common-wealth what≈øoever.

div.head: XVIII.
div.p:
If it ≈øhall happen hereafter (which God forbid) that any controver≈øies and doubts ≈øhall ari≈øe between the ≈øaid mo≈øt renowned Kings, whereby there may be danger of the interruption
of Commerce and Intercour≈øe between their Subjects, there ≈øhall be publike Monition given to the Subjects on both parts, in all and ≈øingular the Kingdoms and Provinces of each King, and after ≈øuch Monition they ≈øhall have two yeers on both parts to tran≈øport their Merchandizes and Goods, and that no trouble, impediment, or hurt ≈øhall be done in the mean time either to Things or Per≈øons on either part.

div.head: XIX.
div.p: And if during this Peace and Amitie any thing ≈øhall be attempted, committed, or done again≈øt the force and effect thereof by Land, Sea, or Fre≈øh-waters, by any of the ≈øaid Kings, their Heirs and Succe≈ø≈øors, their Va≈ø≈øalls, or Subjects, yet notwith≈øtanding this Peace and Amitie ≈øhall remain in ≈øtrength and vertue, and the attempters and offenders onely, and none others, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed for ≈øuch their attempts.

div.head: XX.
div.p:
Item, It is concluded and accorded that the pre≈øent Peace and Confederation ≈øhall not derogate from the Leagues and Confederations heretofore
made and contracted between the mo≈øt renowned King of Great BRITAIN, and other Kings, Princes, and Common wealths, but that the ≈øaid Leagues and Confederations ≈øhall be firmly kept, and ≈øhall hereafter remain in full ≈øtrength, notwith≈øtanding this Treaty of Peace.
